name: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
description: Take control of Lara and her new partner Totec, a Mayan tribesman, and uncover the ancient artifact known as the "Mirror of Smoke" in this all new action adventure game.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / Vista / XP   Processor: 3+ GHz Intel or 2.5+ GHZ AMD   Memory: 1 GB RAM (XP) / 2 GB RAM (Vista)   Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 6 Series (6800GT or better) / ATI 1300XT or better    Hard Drive: 7GB    Sound: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card and drivers

reviews.review_text: A pretty 'Tomb Raider-tastic' CO-OP Game for around 10 hours!
Love It x)

Brilliant game ! Really addictive gameplay and excellent co-op gameplay. Can be played solo just as well by the way. (but is still more fun when you play it with a friend).   This is not your standard action adventure-Tomb Raider game. The game has an isometric view and is all about small puzzles and killing enemies, while still collecting treasures. The awesome graphics really add to the atmosphere and the level (not Steam) achievements keep things fresh and interesting, with a high replayability.   As I said before, the game truly shines in co-op mode where you actually have to depend on each other to complete objectives.  Lara Croft And The Guardian Of Light lasts about 6-7 hours or so, depending on if you're a collector or not.  Highly recommended !  [Rating: 88/100]

Great twin stick shooter with lots of collectibles. You can power up your character with health upgrades, ammo upgrades and even find and use more weapons. Totec uses his shield to help boost Lara upward and throw his spears on the walls for Lara to do some parkour action. Both of these mechanics are a must and can not be avoided. CONS: - Storyline, really bland. - Odd bug here and there, but nothing to harm immersion. - If you do local co-op you cannot continue your progress from a save point if you return to online co-op. Very enjoyable isometric strategy / shooter / puzzler. Definitely recommended if you're a fan of Tomb Raider even though it deviates from the 3d norm. I'm not particularly a fan of tomb raider and I enjoyed it.  The story is that a curse/god is released and you play as Lara adventuring your way through many levels then do a boss battle to put the boss back into his prison.  The game consists of shooting, dodging and solving puzzles in roughly equal measure. If you rush the game without the extras you'll have it done in 3 - 5 hours. These are 3 - 5 very enjoyable hours and well worth the price.  The levels offer a challenge but aren't too hard and you can generally figure out what you have to do quickly. This is no hardcore puzzler, it's a casual puzzler. In the levels there are lots of optional puzzles which reward you with various things. There are also optional tombs containing puzzles that reward you with very nice extra things.  There are a few things to help you along, and this is where the strategy comes in. You can hold 3 weapons plus unlimited low-damage bombs and your spear (which despite being the weakest damage weapon will be required quite often for puzzle solving). You can hold 2 artifacts and 1 relic, which change the attributes of things like defense, speed and attack in varying ways. The relic is only activated after you've killed enough enemies without being hurt, or after picking up enough diamonds and when you take another hit, the relic effects are gone. The ammo is very simple. It's an ammo pool for all weapons (except spear which takes no ammo) and the more powerful weapons use more ammo per shot, simple as that. This is all introduced gradually, and does sound confusing, but it's easy to master once you've been playing a little while and the artifacts and relics allow you a few options that can turn a battle where you haven't got a hope around.  Checkpoints are frequent which is great. And you can quit the game and it'll resume from your last checkpoint next time.  The graphics get a bit repetative - lots of beige and brown rooms with stairs and pathways. But the action flows nicely and you're so busy either battling or figuring out where to go next that you don't really care.  Lastly the boss fight was thoroughly enjoyable. It wasn't particularly challenging on normal difficulty, but it lasted a few minutes and didn't get stale or boring.  There are four gripes I have. 1. There are times when the aim-assist (you'll need it, really) can let you down, this is especially frustrating with the weapons that take lots of ammo per shot, but mostly it was very good. 2. Jumping gaps can also be slightly irritating if you misjudge the direction of the controller. 3. The mission briefing pauses the game to pop up on screen. This can break a nice flow you have and left me saying 'I know, I read it before, just let me play damnit'. However, these are necessary so you know what you're doing. 4. It's too easy on normal difficulty.  One last thing. In one screenshot you see spiders. There are many spiders in this game. Nothing really pounces and there are no jumpscares.

While I've never considered myself a big fan of the Tomb Raider series, I have played a fair share of them, especially the earlier games. I have also delved into the newer chapters, such as Underworld and Legend, but I must admit that the one which really stands out to me, is also the one that completely breaks the formula: Guardian of Light. Rather than the traditional jumping puzzles and third person combat, we get isometric, arcade-like, twin-stick shooting and some of the best puzzles I've seen in any action game, ever. On top of this add gorgeous graphics, satisfying weapons and incredible coop gameplay, and you have a real winner. If I had any say in the matter, Tomb Raider would continue in this style for the foreseeable future, and never return to the dreary platforming of old.

This game differs from other Lara Croft 'Tomb Raider' games in that the camera is set much further away from your character allowing to see much more of the play field - think The Legend of Zelda, A Link To The Past on the SNES ... The co op option shines more than I expected - each player has unique abilities and both players must work together to solve the puzzles ... although you play the same levels in co op, they have all been altered so that each player must use their special abilities in cooperation with the other player to get past each level. Its a lot of fun in co op with plenty of laughs when you or the other goofs up. At the price, its a no brain-er and MUST BUY ... 9/10 score from me.

This is my favorite 'surprise' of 2010. I'd never played a Lara Croft game, but as soon I played the demo for this I wanted to keep playing. Throw in co-op and I was sold.  GAMEPLAY: It has the isometric view of Diablo, with the twin-stick movement/shooting of Geometry Wars, and platforming and puzzles and treasure hunting and customizable weapon load-outs. The hardest puzzles are in optional challenge rooms, so even if you're not great at solving puzzles, you can keep playing.   CO-OP: Each player has unique abilties, but they have to use their abilities in concert to get through the game and solve puzzles. For example, Lara has a grappling hook, which she can use to create rope bridges for her partner, Totec, to cross. Meanwhile, Totec has spears that he can throw into walls which Lara can use as platforms to reach higher places. There's also separate scoreboards, so you can even compete against each other for the highest score while solving puzzles together!  Play it!

I plugged in a XBox-type Logitech controller I got for another game and had better luck. I don't know that I'll put much more time into it... I'm more of a first-person shooter kinda gal. Perhaps if they at least had worked in Diablo, Starcraft, etc. type mouse controls I might get into it more easily.  So, summary: look at screenshots and vids. If this is the type of game you like, get it. If you're a fan of the Tomb Raider FPS but don't really play this kind of top-down isometric thing much, think twice.

If you are a fan of the Tomb Raider series, you will love this. It's like a top down approach to a classic Tomb Raider game. Good action, a range of weapons, puzzles ranging from easy to hard, etc.  There are optional puzzle rooms which will give you more powerful weapons or artifacts that will increase your stats. These are usually more challenging but are worth the reward.  There is a high replayability factor as each level comes with a number of challenges, such as finishing the level within a certain time frame, finding hidden blocks or areas, finding all ten red skulls, et cetera. These also reward you with better weapons or artifacts, and sometimes new costumes.  The game has a good difficulty curve, starting off relatively easy and becoming more difficult, with the last two or three levels being quite challenging (I played on hard combat difficulty).  In essence, good combat, good puzzles, relatively mediocre story (although that fits in perfectly with the original Tomb Raider series before the reboot) and plenty of replayability. Definitely worth it for a Tomb Raider fan. I'm looking forward to the sequel.
